title: Paragraph Organization
what: Paragraph Organization refers to how sentences are arranged to form a clear, logical, and meaningful paragraph. It helps readers understand the message easily.
tutorial:
Example Tutorial:

Topic Sentence: Dogs are great pets.
Supporting Sentences: They are loyal. They protect their owners. They are fun to play with.
Concluding Sentence: That is why many people love keeping dogs.
steps:
1. Start with a topic sentence that tells the main idea.
  2. Add supporting sentences with facts or examples.
  3. End with a concluding sentence that wraps up the idea.

sections.title: Types of Paragraphs
sections.what: Types of Paragraphs show different ways a paragraph can be used like to describe, narrate, explain, or convince.
sections.tutorial:
Example:

Descriptive: The sunset painted the sky with orange and pink.
Narrative: I woke up late and rushed to school.
Expository: Photosynthesis is how plants make food.
Persuasive: We should recycle more to save the planet.
sections.steps:
1. Choose a purpose (describe, narrate, explain, or persuade).
  2. Write a topic sentence based on the purpose.
  3. Add supporting sentences related to your purpose.
  4. Close with a strong concluding sentence.

sections.title: Descriptive Paragraph
sections.what: Descriptive Paragraph paints a picture using words to describe a person, place, or thing.
sections.tutorial: The flowers in the garden were bright and colorful, filling the air with a sweet scent.
sections.steps:
1. Pick what to describe (place, object, person).
  2. Use sensory words (see, hear, smell, touch, taste).
  3. Add details to create a strong image.
  4. End with a summary of the description.

sections.title: Narrative Paragraph
sections.what: Narrative Paragraph tells a story or event in order.
sections.tutorial: Yesterday, I lost my keys. I searched everywhere until I found them under the couch.
sections.steps:
1. Think of a story or event.
  2. Write the topic sentence to introduce the story.
  3. Tell the events in order.
  4. End with what happened in the end.

sections.title: Expository Paragraph
sections.what: Expository Paragraph explains facts, ideas, or steps clearly.
sections.tutorial: To make a sandwich, first get bread. Then add meat and veggies. Finally, put the slices together.
sections.steps:
1. Choose a topic to explain.
  2. Write a clear topic sentence.
  3. Give details or steps in order.
  4. End with a short summary.

sections.title: Persuasive Paragraph
sections.what: Persuasive Paragraph tries to convince the reader to agree with an opinion.
sections.tutorial: School should start later. Students will get more sleep and focus better in class.
sections.steps:
1. Pick a strong opinion.
  2. Start with a topic sentence showing your opinion.
  3. Give reasons and examples.
  4. End by repeating your opinion strongly.

sections.title: Parts of a Paragraph
sections.what: Parts of a Paragraph are the building blocks that make a paragraph clear and complete.
sections.tutorial:
Topic Sentence: Reading is fun.
Supporting Sentences: It helps us learn new words. It makes our imagination grow.
Concluding Sentence: That's why I love to read.
sections.steps:
1. Begin with the main idea in the topic sentence.
  2. Write 2-3 supporting sentences with examples.
  3. End with a concluding sentence.

sections.title: Topic Sentence
sections.what: Topic Sentence shows the main idea of the paragraph.
sections.steps:
1. Choose one clear main idea.
  2. Write it in a short and clear sentence.

sections.title: Supporting Sentences
sections.what: Supporting Sentences give details, examples, or facts to support the topic sentence.
sections.tutorial: It makes our heart strong. It helps us stay active. It also reduces stress.
sections.steps:
1. Think of 2-3 ideas that support the topic.
  2. Write one idea per sentence.
  3. Keep the sentences connected to the topic.

sections.title: Concluding Sentence
sections.what: Concluding Sentence ends the paragraph by repeating the idea or giving a summary.
sections.tutorial: Thatâ€™s why exercise is important for everyone.
sections.steps:
1. Restate the main idea.
  2. Use a sentence that gives closure to the paragraph.

sections.title: Paragraph Transitions
sections.what: Paragraph Transitions are words or phrases used to connect ideas smoothly between sentences or paragraphs.
sections.tutorial: Examples: First, Next, In addition, However, Finally
sections.steps:
1. Choose a transition that fits your idea flow.
  2. Use it at the start of a new sentence or paragraph.
  3. Make sure it helps the paragraph sound connected.

sections.title: Unity and Coherence
sections.what: Unity and Coherence make sure all parts of the paragraph talk about one idea and flow smoothly.
sections.tutorial:
Unity: All sentences talk about one topic.
Coherence: Sentences are connected with proper order and transitions.
sections.steps:
1. Stick to one main idea.
  2. Use logical order for your sentences.
  3. Add transitions to connect ideas.
  4. Read again to check if everything makes sense together.
